newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan CPC to meet partners over Ecuador dispute.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan CPC to meet partners over Ecuador dispute.

text.p: Taiwan's Chinese Petroleum Corp said it and four partners would meet on Friday to discuss ways to continue exploring for oil in Ecuador, which has threatened to halt their operations.
"Our representative in Ecuador will meet our partners on Friday to discuss the Ecuador government's plan to revise contracts," Chinese Petroleum vice president Pan Wen-yen told Reuters on Thursday.

The head of Ecuador state oil company Petroecuador, Paticio Lopez, said this week the government would revise all contracts with foreign companies extracting crude from Ecuadoran soil "so that each one becomes a benefit for the state."
Pan said Chinese Petroleum learned of Ecuador's requests from its partner, Marxus Ecuador Inc, also known as Maxus.
Another Chinese Petroleum official said it appeared that Ecuador's government was demanding a stake in their joint venture.
Chinese Petroleum officials said the company hoped to continue oil exploration in Ecuador despite Quito's bid to revise foreign firms' contracts.
"Chinese Petroleum will try to stay there to continue its oil exploration projects," oil exploration director Yeh Tien-shun said.
Yeh said Taiwan's oil monopoly would study any regulatory changes proposed or made by the Ecuador government.
Chinese Petroleum has a joint oil drilling operation in Ecuador's Block 16 with daily oil production of 30,000 barrels and in Block 17, which has yet to produce, Yeh said.
Maxus holds 35 percent of the joint venture while Chinese Petroleum's subsidiary Overseas Petroleum and Investment Corp holds 31 percent, a Chinese Petroleum document showed.
Nomeco Ecuador Oil Company has 14 percent and Canam Offshore Ltd and Murphy Ecuador Oil Co each hold 10 percent, it said.
Chinese Petroleum officials would not comment on how talks with Ecuador might proceed, but said they agreed in principle that foreign investment must bring benefits to the local economy.
"Foreign investors like Chinese Petroleum should include plans to benefit the local people," Yeh said.
Another Chinese Petroleum official said it was unlikely the Ecuadoran army would occupy Block 16, despite news reports that it might.
"There is no need for Ecuador's government to use the army to occupy any block," Chinese Petroleum official Liao Pai-fon said. "We will wait and see what deals the Ecuador government wants to reach."
